ParentLink Kinship Caregiver Virtual Support Group: Raising a child that is not biologically your own comes with unique challenges, especially amidst the current world crisis, but a collaborative effort was formed by ParentLink by partnering with MU Extension professionals and the New Madrid County Family Resource Center to create a Kinship Caregiver Virtual Support Group. This support group is being held virtually via Zoom, weekly on Thursdays from 10am to 11am.

ParentLink provides free parenting information and support to all Kinship Caregivers throughout Missouri through these weekly support group sessions. You can expect useful information from guest speakers and support to help you navigate your role as a kinship caregiver.

shared_text:
BHS Art
May 14 at 4:02 PM ·

Madalynn Gregory is the artist of the month for April.

For the second semester, Portfolio students created a themed series. Their series consist of a cohesive body of work based on a central theme. Students created each piece with the same medium to maintain the cohesiveness of their series.

This painting is 1 of 3 in Madalynn's series, and is of a woman with cancer. The following is taken from Madalynn’s artist statement:

“My subject matter is women outside of the beauty standards. The women that I chose to paint are beautiful in their own way. These people do not fit the beauty standards of today’s world. I love supporting other women and I firmly believe that all women are beautiful. Each and every woman has some pretty amazing and beautiful qualities.”

Well done Madalynn!

It is with great sadness, yet understanding during this difficult time, the closure of school for the remainder of the school year. Governor Parson, during his daily address, ordered all Missouri schools closed until the end of the school year.

While school buildings are closed, this does not mean that school is over for the year. We will continue to educate our students for the remainder of the originally scheduled school year through Alternative Instructional Methods.

As a District, we have many hurdles to work through in the next few weeks including honoring commencement, prom, and our staff and students. We will send communication early next week with additional information.

In the meantime, please enjoy your time with your families this extended weekend.

Dr. Sarah Marriott
Superintendent of Schools

Congratulations to Marina and her teacher Margie Brimer. It is a great day to be a Pirate!

shared_text:
Boonville High School Silver Pirate Band
December 12, 2019 at 4:41 PM ·

Music will be in the air as the Boonville Silver Pirate Band presents a Holiday Concert on Sunday, December 15, at 2:00 p.m. in the Laura Speed Elliott Auditorium. The concert is free and open to the public.

The concert will open with And the Herald Angels Sang arranged by James Swearingen and includes three beautiful Christmas classics, Angels from the Realms of Glory, Angels We Have Heard on High!, and Hark! The Herald Angels Sing. A medley of many holiday favorites including Frosty the Snowman and Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas are artfully arranged by John Edmondson in the selection titled Christmas Recollections. Missouri composer Claude T. Smith created a beautiful arrangement of Adeste Fidelis that opens with a majestic statement of this beloved melody by the trumpets. The concert will conclude with a transcription of Greensleeves, a rich lyrical melody to set the mood for the upcoming holidays.

Celebrate the season with the Silver Pirate Band beginning at 2:00 p.m. in the Laura Speed Elliott Middle School auditorium.

FUTURE BUSINESS LEADERS: FBLA students attended a conference in Denver, Colorado to sharpen their skills and broaden their leadership knowledge.

#WeArePirates
shared_text:
Pirate Press
December 3, 2019 at 10:17 AM ·

FBLA Goes To Denver
The third weekend of November, FBLA attended National Fall Leadership Conference in Denver, Colorado. Boonville took five students to the conference: Michael Browning, Clint Penny, Kyle Platt, Chris Weisner, and Amanda Mize. There were over 2,000 students in attendance, and Missouri had the largest attendance with over 500 attendees. The conference consisted of two keynote speakers and workshops. The workshops educated students on the steps to growing your own business, ethics, and how to increase membership in FBLA chapters at home.
The Denver trip may have been focused around the conference, but the group had many opportunities to explore the great city of Denver. From walking around the 16th Street mall to exploring Red Rocks Amphitheater, this trip is never to be forgotten. Senior Michael Browning quoted it as “a completely new experience.” This trip truly highlighted what city life is like. For some, it made them realize how much they wanted to move into a city. Others, however, realized that the midwest is their home.
-Amanda Mize, reporter

AMERICAN HERO: Boonville High School ELA I students were treated this morning to a talk presented by Ralph Kalberloh. A sergeant in the Army Air Corps during World War II, Kalberloh was a tail gunner on a B-17 when his crew had to make an emergency bailout over Germany. History came to life as Kalberloh shared information about his position in the Air Corps, experience in flight and after the bailout, time at Nuremberg as a P.O.W, and a salute from General Patton.

Kalberloh was very happy to be named an honorary Pirate by students from BTEC JROTC.

#WeArePirates
shared_text:
Kelly Sanders Smith
October 30, 2019 at 10:31 AM ·

Thanks to some Jefferson City friends, I was able to find a WWII veteran and former POW to speak to all of my students at the high school today. Mr. Ralph Kalberloh held the full attention of almost 200 kids as he told his story. At the end, some of my students, who are also in Jr ROTC, presented Mr. Kalberloh with a Boonville Pirate hat to make him an “honorary Pirate” for the day.
Abowk Florist donated the Boonville Pirate Hat, Maggie’s Bar and Grill donated lunch for Mr. Kalberloh and his wife, and the Boonville Museum and Friends of Historic Boonville offered to host them for tours.
We are rounding out our WWII/Unbroken unit learning about empathy through the stories of real people. 💙
I’m humbled!

FIGHTING FIRES: In Mrs. Van Dyke's Robotics class at LSE, we have been discussing that when fires break out, the conditions can become extremely dangerous for humans. One way to help combat these fires is by using firefighting robots with water cannons.

The Edison Robots used in class are LEGO compatible. Students are using bricks (and their engineering skills) to build their own water tank robots. They will then program the tanks to drive into a "fire" and shoot a jet of water (represented by a rubber band).

Edison Robots were funded by a grant from the Boonville R-1 Education Foundation.

What's the school district building? Well, nothing at this time.

This is actually a maintenance shed and restrooms built by the City of Boonville on City property.

When will district construction work start on bond projects?
Since the school district is a public entity, we are required to follow strict financial guidelines. One important component is accurately following bidding procedures and laws. We are currently finalizing renovation and repair plans and anticipate putting projects out for bids in late winter. We hope to start projects in late April/May.

We have to carefully time our projects so the construction has the least impact on our students' school day.
